Inputs

Inputs are a form element that can be used to allow users to enter freeform text.

Guidelines

  • For best scanability, field labels should appear above the input.  Alternatively, they can be left aligned on the left side of the input.
  • Clearly distinguish required or optional input fields.
    • If most fields on the screen are required, explicitly designate fields as ‘optional’ using small text.
    • If most fields on the screen are optional, indicate required fields using an asterisk (*).
  • Use the jQuery Validation library included in UXFrame to validate required fields. For each validation message, provide the user a clear, concise description of the validation issue and how to resolve it.
    • In situations where the default validation message presentation causes layout issues, tooltips may be used instead of small text below each field.
  • Avoid pre-populating default values unless you’re confident that it is applicable to at least 90% of potential users.
  • Use example text below an input for additional instructions or examples of expected data format.

Documentation

Bootstrap Documentation

Modifiers

Class Description
.uxf-is-required add class to a label element to apply required styles
.uxf-is-optional add class to a label element to apply optional styles

Javascript

To validate inputs, use the jQuery Validation library included in UXFrame Plus and add .uxf-jquery-validate to the .uxf containing element.

Convert from UXFrame v1 to v2

  1. Remove .error class on form elements, and add .has-error class to parent .input-box elements.
  2. Change .input-box to .form-group.
  3. Add .form-control to all input, select, and form-control elements
  4. Add .uxf-jquery-validate to the .uxf containing element if using validation.
